knowledge: Jaundice Jaundice  Jaundice is a yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes that results from accumulation of bilirubin in the blood. It can be caused by the liver's inability to excrete bilirubin, blockage of the bile ducts that excrete bilirubin, or excessive breakdown of red blood cells.  The causes of jaundice are diverse. In pre-hepatic jaundice, excessive destruction of red blood cells leads to increased levels of bilirubin in the bloodstream, which the liver cannot excrete rapidly enough. In hepatic jaundice, the liver is damaged or altered so that it cannot excrete bilirubin rapidly enough. In post-hepatic jaundice, there is a blockage in the bile ducts that leads to accumulation of bilirubin.  Jaundice can also be caused by certain medications, cancer, and infections, such as hepatitis Jaundice Jaundice
